Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Case Marking and the Left Periphery in Dinka

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Human language is simultaneously a complex function of the human mind and a vital cultural resource for communities of speakers. With both of these facts in mind, this project investigates the sentence structure of Dinka, an understudied Nilotic language with unique structural properties, spoken in South Sudan and in a growing diaspora community in the US. Many refugee communities in the US face difficulties in preserving and transmitting their native language, particularly when there are few published resources describing the language. Working with the Boston diaspora community, Mr. Coppe van Urk will provide in-depth documentation and analysis of the language, which will be made available to the community. In addition, this study will produce a collection of Dinka children's stories as a resource for the refugee community.

At the same time, this project will investigate an array of aspects of Dinka grammar that challenge current ideas about features usually thought to be common to all languages. In particular, this research looks at the syntax of "long-distance dependencies" (questions and similar constructions) and their interaction with case and agreement. Most theories of syntactic structure view the grammar of long-distance dependencies as entirely distinct from the processes that govern case marking and verb agreement, reflecting the facts of well-studied languages. In Dinka, however, long-distance dependencies go hand in hand with changes in case marking and agreement, suggesting that this separation is not universal. Research on Dinka thus promises to advance and change our view of several fundamental aspects of human language.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The investigation of understudied languages is inexpensive and has the potential to produce insights of real value into the properties of human cognition, and to allow us to highlight and preserve the diversity of natural languages. This project investigated the South Sudanese language Dinka, a greatly understudied language, in the refugee community in Boston. This examination of Dinka has yielded important results with clear repercussions for fundamental questions about the structure of natural language, in particular those related to syntactic displacement.

One of the major findings of syntactic theory, first pointed out in Chomsky 1957, is that sentences are constructed not just by a simple combinatorial operation (putting two words together), but also through a displacement operation (moving one word to another positions in the sentence). Forming a question in English, for example, requires moving the phrase that is questioned (consider: "Kim thinks Sam likes those books" vs. "Which books does Kim think Sam likes?").

A long-standing problem in the study of this displacement operation is that such movement seems to come in two fundamentally different types: (i) potentially unbounded movements such as the one involved in questions, wh-movement (collectively known as A'-movements), and (ii) more local displacement such as in passivization ("Jess read those books" vs. "Those books were read by Jess"), known as A-movements. That this division systematically correlates with a large set of syntactic differences across languages is surprising if all sentence building in the human cognitive system happens by the same mechanisms, which is the most attractive hypothesis (e.g. Chomsky 1995). In the dissertation resulting from this project, it is shown that Dinka provides a crucial piece of the typology of movement, in that it reveals that some languages do not display robust evidence of this distinction at all. Instead, all displacement in Dinka has properties of both. On the basis of this, the dissertation provides a comprehensive new theory of the A/A'-distinction, which can account for the Dinka pattern and also allows us to maintain a simple and uniform view of how the language faculty constructs sentences. In this way, the study of Dinka has proven to be able to provide important insight even into the mechanisms at work in basic English sentences.

In addition to this, the study has led to a number of unanticipated results. The first of these is reported in the dissertation. A unique pronoun copying construction in Dinka, found and documented in the course of carrying out fieldwork, provides novel evidence for the Copy Theory of Movement (Chomsky 1995) and has repercussions for the crosslinguistic study of pronouns. A journal article documenting these results is under review. In addition to this, the research uncovered significant new facts for the study of voice systems (Erlewine, Levin, Van Urk, in prep.), verb-second, a characteristic with well-established effects on the syntax of Germanic languages (Van Urk, in prep.), and resumption (Van Urk, upcoming).

Finally, this project has resulted in the collection of Dinka children's stories, to be made available to the Boston refugee community. The publication and availability of such materials will aid a refugee community in preserving its language and culture. In this way, the project has positive effects on the preservation and documentation of cultural diversity.
